journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering

title-group.article-title: The transverse vibration of high-speed rolls

article-meta.aff: Faculty of Engineering, The British University in Dubai, UAE

author-notes.corresp: A Abdul-Ameer, Faculty of Engineering, The British University in Dubai, PO Box 345015, Dubai, UAE. Email: alaa.ameer@buid.ac.ae

abstract.p: The transverse, dynamic deflection of high-speed, wide-faced, composite tubular rolls is investigated. General procedures are proposed enabling the analysis of inter-connected units comprising both distributed parameter and rigid, pointwise models. Modelling methods, eliminating intermediate variables are employed facilitating the realisation of an overall system, input–output representation. Illustrative studies, detailing the analysis and evaluation process are presented. A high-speed, paper making machine, table roll application is considered. Whirling conditions and the effect of this problem on sheet quality and manufacturing output is commented upon.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In this article, the wide-faced rolls, which are used in the high-speed, sequential, manufacturing operations in the board, paper printing, packaging and textile industries are considered. These elements are costly to produce and maintain owing to exacting specification requirements, surface finish quality and their dynamic characteristics, see for example, Smith1 and Long and Hsieh.2

Typically, machine speeds of up to 6500 ft/min are encountered in these industries where continuous production schedules spanning 2–3 weeks are usually required. To accommodate the sheet specification tolerances imposed, roll cambering, so that upon sagging the roll, contact profile is free from deflection, is regularly achieved via contouring, during final roll turning, grinding and polishing operations.

Without these fine limits manufacturing consistency, sheet thickness, strength and absorbency would be compromised. Of equal importance, interruptions in production owing to uneven wear, differential loading and sheet tearing may be experienced resulting in expensive shutdown, maintenance and refit costs.

Costs, mass–inertia and dynamic deflection penalties are also instrumental in minimising the tube wall thicknesses, of the many machine rolls used in these industries, at the design stage. Unfortunately, this also invites elastic deformation and dynamic deflection and both of these effects are constantly perturbed owing to internally generated noise, shock and vibration, as detailed in Beards3 and Genta.4

These variations are difficult to suppress in practice following initial design, installation and commissioning. However, the tendency towards wider machine construction, elevated operating speeds and capital cost economies all promote and contribute to machine vibration, as in Bartlett and Whalley,5 and this remains as an endemic problem.

In this regard, the effect of transverse vibrations when employing wide-faced rolls is difficult to counter. Ultimately, addressing this problem during the design process, see for example Aleyaasin et al.,6 is of fundamental importance.

Otherwise, the manifestation of dynamic bowing, with the onset of whirling conditions, perpetrates breakdowns, production and consistency problems. This is an active operational condition which would not be detected via static inspections and from steady-state measurements, as discussed in Rao7 and Aleyaasin et al.8
Consequently, unexplained production problems would be encountered. These difficulties may also be speed and sheet grade dependent, appearing to occur as intermittent faults of unknown origin.

Procedures enabling the determination of whirling conditions are investigated herein. The effects of various running speeds on this condition are also determined, for a typical MG machine, table roll application.

However, of necessity during the construction process, wide-faced machine rolls are carefully balanced ensuring smooth, even, vibration-free running. Otherwise, the remaining dynamic properties are largely addressed via finite element techniques at the design stage. With this procedure, the number of eigenvalues and eigenvectors computed becomes large, as attempts to improve the accuracy of the results obtained are incorporated, by increasing the number of finite elements included in the analysis.
Ultimately, this leads to computational difficulties where multiplication round-off errors contaminate the predictions.

In the procedures advocate herein, a novel analytical approach to the problem of the transverse vibrations, of wide-faced machine rolls, is introduced. Unlike earlier methods, accurate, unambiguous results indicating the operational speed, and in particular the fundamental, critical speed, which should be avoided, are computed.

sec.title: Distributed–lumped parameter roll models
sec.p:
The roll models considered herein and in practice have the structure shown in Figure 1. Essentially, the central roll body comprises thin-walled tube. Both the left and right ends of the roll consist of cast iron centres with sold steel shafts which are supported by bearings, as considered in Whalley and Ebrahimi.9 Figure 1.
Roll general arrangement. Vi(s)=Yi(s),θi(s),Mi(s),Qi(s) 1≤i≤8Yi(s)=Roll deflection at locationi, θi(s)=Roll slope at locationiMi(s)=Bending moment on roll at locationi, Qi(s)=Shear force on roll at locationi. .

In the analysis following, the bearing shafts and tube elements will be treated as relatively rigid elements with lumped inertia and stiffness properties. The cast iron centres at each end of the assembly will also be assumed to be relatively rigid discs so that dynamically the arrangement comprises a lumped, lumped, distributed, lumped, lumped configuration, for analysis purposes as in Bartlett and Whalley.10

The flexible, distributed parameter shafts and tubes may be described in terms of the deflection y, slope θ, bending moment m and shear force q at their left and right ends, respectively. The derivation of the matrix equation for a parallel, flexible, distributed parameter tube element is presented in Appendix 2.

As a consequence for the left-half tube, of length l1/2, external diameter do, internal diameter di the governing equation, as shown in Figure 6 is (1)(Y4(s),θ4(s),My4(s),Qy4(s))T =F(s)(Y3(s),θ3(s),My3(s),Qy3(s))T where in equation (1) F(s)=[f112γf2-Cl22γ2f3-Cl32γ3f4-γ2lf4f1-Cl2γf2-Cl22γ2f3γ22l2Cf3γ2lf4f112γf2γ32Cl3f2γ22l2Cf3-γ2lf4f1] and (2)f1=(coshγ+cosγ)/2 (3)f2=sinhγ+sinγ (4)f3=coshγ-cosγ and (5)f4=sinhγ-sinγ where in equations (2) to (5) (6)γ=Γ1/2l where l is the length of the distributed parameter shaft with (7)Γ1/2=s1/2(LC)1/4 (8)C=1EI (9)-12ptandL=ρA

sec.title: Fundamental matrix truncation
sec.p: From equations (2) to (5), it is clear that the truncated forms for f1, f2, f3 and f4 are (10)f1=1+γ44!+γ88!+… (11)f2=2(γ+γ55!+γ99!+…) (12)f3=γ2+2γ66!+2γ1010!+… and (13)f4=2(γ33!+γ77!+γ1111!+…)

The truncated forms of equations (10) to (13) are alternate even and odd power series each having a power ratio of γ4 indicating very rapid convergence characteristics for γ<1, which would normally be the case for mechanical system elements. Substituting for f1, f2, f3 and f4 in equation (1) results in the elements of F(s) becoming f11(s)=f1=1+γ44!+γ88!+…f21(s)=-γ2lf4=-1l(γ43!+γ87!+γ1211!+…)f31(s)=γ22l2Cf3=12l2C(γ4+2γ86!+2γ1210!+…)f41(s)=-γ32Cl3f2=-1Cl3(γ4+γ85!+γ129!+…)f12(s)=l2γf2=l(1+γ45!+γ89!+…)f22(s)=f1=1+γ44!+γ88!f32(s)=γ2Cf4=1C(γ43!+γ87!+γ1211!+…)f42(s)=γ22Cl2f3=1Cl2(γ4+2γ86!+2γ1210!+…)f13(s)=-Cl22γ2f3=-Cl22(1+2γ46!+2γ810!+…)f23(s)=-Cl2γf2=-Cl(1+γ45!+γ89!+…)f33(s)=f1=1+γ44!+γ88!+…f43(s)=γ2lf4=1l(γ43!+γ87!+γ1211!+…)f14(s)=-Cl32γ3f4=-Cl3(13!+γ47!+γ811!+…)f24(s)=-Cl22γ2f3=-Cl22(1+2γ46!+2γ810!+…)f34(s)=l2γf2=l(1+γ45!+γ89!+…)f44(s)=f1=1+γ44!+γ88!+… since γ=Γ1/2l=s1/2(LC)1/4l

It is clear that every element fi,j(s) 1≤i,j≤4 is a rational function in s following the substitution for γ. However, this property is for all truncations, irrespective of the number of terms included in the series expansions of f1, f2, f3 and f4.

The lowest frequency of vibration or whirl would be detected when restricting the series expansions of f1, f2, f3 and f4 to the least number of terms. Thereafter, higher resonant frequencies would become evident with the inclusion of higher powers of γ whilst refining the original estimate for the fundamental frequency of oscillation.

sec.title: Cast iron centre, steel bearing shaft and tube gyroscopic models
sec.p: The input–output vectors from the distributed parameter tube model, given in ‘Distributed–lumped parameter roll models’ section become the input–output vectors for the lumped parameter models. In this regard, the model for a rigid rotor, with polar moment of inertia J and mass m, as shown in Figure 1, would arise from the transformed relationship. Y3(s)=Y2(s)θ3(s)=θ2(s)My3(s)=-JΩ(sθ2(s))+My2(s)Qy3(s)=ms2Y2(s)+Qy2(s)

All the relatively pointwise rigid rotor equations are similar in that the deflections and slopes at the input and output ends are approximately equal. Also, the bending moments and shear stress at the output ends are equal to those at the input end, minus the gyroscopic couple and plus the acceleration force, respectively.

Hence (14)(Y3(s),θ3(s),My3(s),Qy3(s))T=R1(s)(Y2(s),θ2(s), My2(s),Qy2(s))T-11ptand(Y7(s),θ7(s),My7(s),Qy7(s))T=R2(s)(Y6(s),θ6(s), My6(s),Qy6(s))T where in equation (14), since the roll is symmetrical about the vertical centre line R(s)=R1(s)=R2(s)=[100001000-JcΩs10mcs2001]

Also, the steel bearing shafts are governed by (15)(Y2(s),θ2(s),My2(s),Qy2(s))T=B1(s)(Y1(s),θ1(s), My1(s),Qy1(s))T-11ptand(Y8(s),θ8(s),My8(s),Qy8(s))T=B2(s)(Y7(s),θ7(s), My7(s),Qy7(s))T where again in equation (15) for symmetrical configurations B(s)=B1(s)=B2(s)=[100001000-JsΩs10mss2001]
Also, the gyroscopic couple experienced by the roll tube is given by the equation (16)(Y6(s),θ6(s),My6(s),Qy6(s))T=G(s)(Y5(s),θ5(s), My5(s),Qy5(s))T where in equation (16) G(s)=[100001000-JTΩs100001]
This completes the lumped parameter element modelling.

sec.title: Overall roll model
sec.p: Now that specific models have been derived for the flexible, distributed parameter and the rigid, steel and cast iron centre components, a complete model for the overall roll can be easily assembled. If the equation for the left steel bearing shaft is (17)(Y2(s),θ2(s),My2(s),Qy2(s))T=B1(s)(Y1(s),θ1(s), My1(s),Qy1(s))T the equation for the left cast iron centre is (18)(Y3(s),θ3(s),My3(s),Qy3(s))T=R1(s)(Y2(s),θ2(s), My2(s),Qy2(s))T followed by the left-half tube equation (19)(Y4(s),θ4(s),My4(s),Qy4(s))T=F(s)(Y3(s),θ3(s), My3(s),Qy3(s))T and gyroscopic equation (20)(Y5(s),θ5(s),My5(s),Qy5(s))T=G(s)(Y4(s),θ4(s), My4(s),Qy4(s))T followed by the right-half tube equation (21)(Y6(s),θ6(s),My6(s),Qy6(s))T=F(s)(Y5(s),θ5(s), My5(s),Qy5(s))T with the right cast iron centre equation of (22)(Y7(s),θ7(s),My7(s),Qy7(s))T=R2(s)(Y6(s),θ6(s), My6(s),Qy6(s))T and finally the right steel bearing shaft equation is (23)(Y8(s),θ8(s),My8(s),Qy8(s))T=B2(s)(Y7(s),θ7(s), My7(s),Qy7(s))T completing the series component analysis.

sec.title: High-speed MG machine table rolls
sec.p: In this section, the theoretical derivation given earlier will be applied to assess the whirling frequency of a high-speed table roll. The parameters for this element, in accordance with Figures 1 and 6, are -1pc2m≤lt (Roll face width) ≤6m0.08m≤Do≤0.2m,roll tube wall thickness=5mmTube material density: ρt=7800kg/m3Steel bearing shafts density:ρs=7800kg/m3,ls=0.3m, ds=0.02m, Js=0.18378×10-4kgm2, ms=0.73514kgFor the steel tube:Ct=1ItEt Lt=ρtAt

In this case, from the dimensions given earlier, it is evident that the roll under consideration is symmetrical about the vertical centre line. Hence, as in ‘Distributed–lumped parameter roll models’ section B2(s)=B1(s)=B(s)-11ptandR2(s)=R1(s)=R(s)

Upon eliminating intermediate variables, from equations (17) to (23) (24)(Y8(s),θ8(s),My8(s),Qy8(s))T=H(s)(Y1(s),θ1(s), My1(s),Qy1(s))T H(s)=[I0B¯(s)I][I0R¯(s)I][F11(s)F12(s)F21(s)F22(s)] ×[I0G¯(s)I][F11(s)F12(s)F21(s)F22(s)][I0R¯(s)I] ×[I0B¯(s)I] where B¯(s)=[0-JsΩsmss20],R¯(s)=[0-JcΩsmcs20]-31ptandG¯(s)=[0-JTΩs00] where in equation (24), the partitions are in 2 × 2 block form and H(s)=[I0R¯(s)+B¯(s)I][F11(s)F12(s)F21(s)F22(s)] ×[I0G¯(s)I][F11(s)F12(s)F21(s)F22(s)][I0R¯(s)+B¯(s)I] yielding, upon dropping the argument (s) H(s)=[(F11+F1 2)2+F1 2{G¯(F11+F1 2Z)+F2 1+F22Z}(F11+F1 2Z)F12+F12(G¯F1 2+F22)(F2 1+F22Z)(F11+F1 2Z)+F22{G¯(F11+F1 2Z)+F2 1+F22Z}F22(G¯F1 2+F22)] where Z=[R¯(s)+B¯(s)]
The boundary conditions, for the roll shown in Figure 1, would require for built-in ends, that [Y8(s)θ8(s)]=[Y1(s)θ1(s)]=[00]
Consequently (25)[00M8Q8]=[H11(s)H1 2(s)H2 1(s)H22(s)][00M1Q1] a solution to equation (25) is only possible if (26)detH1 2(s)=0
If only the leading term of f1,f2,f3andf4 is employed, then (27)F(s)=[11-Ctlt22-Ctlt36-s26LtCtlt31-Ctlt-Ctlt22s22Ltlt2s26Ltlt311s2Ltlts26Ltlt2-s26LtCtlt31]

From equation (27) F11(s)=[11-s26LtCtlt31],F12(s)=-[Ctlt22Ctlt36CtltCtlt22] F21(s)=s2[Ltlt22Ltlt36LtltLtlt22],F22(s)=[11-s26LtCtlt31] and from equation (14), for the cast iron centres and steel bearing shafts Z=[0-(Jc+Js)Ωs(mc+ms)s20] respectively. Upon substituting for F11,F12etc(28)H1 2(s)=(F1 1(s)+F12(s)Z)F12(s)+F12(s) (G¯(s)F1 2(s)+F22(s)) and detH1 2(s) may be evaluated from the algebraic expression for 0≤s=iω≤∞. Alternatively, the complex matrix for H1 2(iω)=X(ω)+iY(ω) may be computed and detH1 2(iω) may be obtained for each frequency.
For the roll under consideration, the Bode diagram for 1/detH1 2(iω) gives an indication of the resonant frequencies as follows:

list-item.p: Constant diameter, variable roll face width. In this case, for the roll shown in Figure 1, with an outside diameter of 0.2 m and roll wall thickness of 5 mm, the dynamic magnification at resonance with Ω = 2500 r/min is shown in Figure 2, for 2m≤lt≤6m. Upon lowering the rotational speed to zero, the resonant frequency remains virtually unchanged. However, with Ω = 0 r/min, the only effectively resistance to dynamic amplification is removed and, as shown in Figure 3, the resonant peak amplitudes become very large for each of the four lengths examined.

Constant face width, variable diameter rolls. In this study, a typical machine roll, face width of 4.0 m will be considered. The roll outside diameter will now be increased from 0.08 to 0.12, 0.16 and then 0.2 m, with the steel tube wall thickness remaining as 5 mm. The Bode diagrams for 1/detH1 2(iω) for these configurations are shown in Figures 4 and 5, where the resonant frequency reduces, as the roll diameter decreases.

caption.p: Bode diagram for (1/detH1 2(iω)) with Ω = 2500 r/min and Do=0.2m,Di=0.19m,2m≤lt(roll face width)≤6m.
Bode diagram for (1/detH1 2(iω)) with Ω = 0 r/min and Do=0.2m,Di=0.19m,2m≤lt(Roll Face Width)≤6m.
Bode diagram for (1/detH1 2(iω)) with Ω = 2500 r/min and lt(Roll Face Width)=4m and0.08m≤Do≤0.2m.
Bode diagram for (1/detH1 2(iω)) with Ω = 0 r/min and lt(Roll Face Width)=4m and0.08m≤Do≤0.2m.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this contribution, the basic analysis procedures enabling the dynamics of wide-faced, machine rolls, comprising steel bearing shafts, cast iron centres and steel tubular bodies were addressed. These rotor assemblies are extensively employed in the paper, board, printing, packaging and textile industries where high-speed operations are encountered.

High capital, manufacturing and operational costs result in the use of thin-walled tubes minimising thereby mass–inertia, deflection and bearing loads. However, this attracts vibration, transverse bowing and torsional dynamics.

With the rapid acceleration requirements toward elevated operational speeds, the transverse, critical speed and bowing problems become an issue. Unfortunately, using current methods of assessment, based on elementary beam theory, the running speed and hence gyroscopic couple which occurs is ignored. Moreover, the whirling speed alone is often the only result which is available, giving no indication of the dynamic amplification, as resonance conditions are approached.

The analysis techniques introduced herein propose new methods which incorporate both the distributed and flexural properties of machine rolls together with the rotational velocity effects. As a result of this modular analysis procedure, rolls and rotor systems for any distributed–lumped modelling composition can be easily constructed.

Effectively, this allows the series assembly of rolls and rotors comprising elements of various diameters, wall thicknesses, lengths and materials. These may have significant elastic deformation and relatively rigid characteristics, reflecting thereby the actual properties of this form of roll–rotor arrangement.

The rolls which operate at the highest rotational velocity are located at the extreme ends of the operation, in paper manufacturing and conversion systems. In this regard, MG table and, at the dry end of the process, winder rolls are particularly vulnerable to dynamic deflection and bowing. The application study herein examines the critical speed problem for wide-faced, MG Yankee machine, table rolls. Various face width and diameter units are analysed to provide comparisons.

As the graphical results show, the dynamic amplification encountered changes owing to the stabilising gyroscopic couple which the rolls experience at higher velocities. However, the problem of accelerating to the operational speed or running at a speed in the vicinity of resonance, would cause roll bowing which would not be detectable from static measurements when Ω = 0 r/min, for example, but would be qualitatively predictable. In order to avoid these problems by design, accurate methods of assessment and critical speed analysis need to be employed. Equally, as with the technique outlined herein, details of the dynamic amplification condition near to resonance needs to be determined, before construction.

As shown in the previous analysis, the key to critical speed evaluation arises from the linearisation of the non-linear, irrational, incomplete Laplace transformed matrix model relating the roll input to output deflection, slope, bending moment and shear force vectors. Owing to the complexity of the elements of this matrix, various quasi-steady state, zero-speed approaches to the transverse vibration problem have been adopted. These application studies give conservative results in that the gyroscopic, stabilising couple has been excluded.

In the case of process system rolls, the composite construction of the roll itself is rarely recognised, in dynamics, leading to further approximations, empirical adjustments and errors. Surprisingly, the main obstacle to improved accuracy is easily overcome in that the linearisation of the 16 elements, of the fundamental matrix, results in rational approximations with the series expansions for each element exhibiting rapid convergence characteristics.

Equally, in the analysis herein, the relatively lumped parameter models for the left and right hand bearing shafts and cast iron housings, for machine rolls, may also be represented by simple linear matrix models. This modular approach enables the formulation, and hence the analysis of, composite shaft-bearing systems where any distributed–distributed, for stepped shafts, or lumped–distributed structure, for rolls and shafts, may be accommodated.

Ultimately, this route to analysis which can easily be extended to longitudinal and torsional vibration analysis would help in the resolution of the many integrity questions arising from finite element procedures.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article considers the critical speed, whirling properties of high-speed rolls and shafts. These elements are extensively used in the textile, paper, board and process industries.

The main problem with the analysis procedures for such elements is that the input–output deflection, slope, bending moment and shear force matrix for these units results in a matrix of non-linear, irrational, incomplete functions in the Laplace variable, as shown in equation (59). This complication, effectively masks any correspondence between the theory presented in the analysis and the system dynamic performance.

However, at the onset of whirling the deflections, slopes, bending moments and shear force changes are relatively small enabling the employment of perturbation analysis. As shown, this is the important step in achieving a rational function response matrix and hence the analytical advantages arising from this.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The authors wish to acknowledge the British University in Dubai for initial funding.

sec.title: Distributed parameter shaft/roll model
sec.p: The equilibrium equations and Newton’s second law may be used to obtain the matrix equation relating the input and output flexible/shaft vectors of (y1(t,x),θ1(t,x),my1(t,x),q1(t,x)) and(y2(t,x),θ2(t,x),my2(t,x),qy2(t,x)) respectively. In the following derivation the argument (t, x) has been omitted and y,θy,my,qy refers to the general deflection, slope, bending moment and shear force in the x–y plane, respectively. The shaft element under consideration is shown in Figure 6.
The bending moment–shear force relationship is (29)qy=ddxmy and from simple beam theory (30)my=-EId2ydx2 Hence (31)qy=-EId3ydx3
Newton’s second law is (32)∂qy∂x=ρA∂2y∂t2 and the velocity of the element at point x is given by (33)∂y∂t=vy
From equations (32) and (33) (34)∂qy∂x=ρA∂vy∂t
Differentiating equation (31) with respect to time and substituting from equation (33) gives (35)∂qy∂t=EI∂3vy∂x3

If now (36)ρA=L and (37)1EI=C then Laplace transforming equation (35) and substituting from equation (37) yields (38)d2Vydx3=-sCQy(x,s) and Laplace transforming equation (34) with respect to time, following the substitution of equation (36) gives (39)dQydx=sLVy(x,s)
If now equation (38) is differentiated with respect to x and considering equation (39) (40)d4Vydx4=-s2LCVy(x,s)
In equation (40) if (41)Γ=s(LC) (42)d4Vydx4+Γ2Vy=0
The solution of equation (42) is (43)Vy(x,s)=AsinhxΓ+BcoshxΓ+C¯sinxΓ +DcosxΓ
Hence, since Y(x,s)=L{y(x,t)} the vertical deflection from the shaft/beam model, transformed, with zero initial conditions is (44)Y(x,s)=AssinhxΓ+BscoshxΓ+C¯ssinxΓ +DscosxΓ
Differentiating equation (44) with respect to x yields (45)ddxY(x,s)=AsΓcoshxΓ+BsΓsinhxΓ +C¯sΓcosxΓ-DsΓsinxΓ so that (46)-EId2Y(x,s)dx2=-Γs(AsinhxΓ+BcoshxΓ -C¯sinxΓ-DcosxΓ)IE
And (47)-EId3Y(x,s)dx3=-ΓΓs(AcoshxΓ+BsinhxΓ -C¯cosxΓ+DsinxΓ)IE
Equations (46) and (47) become (48)-EId2Y(x,s)dx2=My(x,s) (49)-EId2Y(x,s)dx2=Qy(x,s)

Applying boundary conditions to equations (44) and (47) with substitutions from equations (48) and (49) requires that (50)Y(0,s)=B+Ds=Y1 (51)θ(0,s)=Γs(A+C¯)=θ1 (52)My(0,s)=Γs(D-B)EI=My1 (53)Q(0,s)=ΓΓs(C¯-A)EI=Qy1
In matrix form, equations (50) to (53) result in (54)s(Y1,θ1,My1,Qy1)T=X(A,B,C¯,D)T where in equation (54) X=[0101Γ0Γ00-ΓIE0ΓIE-ΓΓIE0ΓΓIE0]
Upon inverting X, the boundary conditions are satisfied if (55)A=s2Γθ1-Cs2ΓΓQy1 (56)B=s2Y1-Cs2ΓMy1 (57)C¯=s2Γθ1+Cs2ΓΓQy1 (58)D=s2Y1+Cs2ΓMy1

The relationship for the input and output vectors can now be determined by putting x = l in equations (44) to (47) and substituting for A, B, C¯ and D from equations (55) to (58). This yields the input–output deflection, slope, applied bending moment and shear force equation (59)(Y2,θ2,My2,Qy2)T=F(s)(Y1,θ1,My1,Qy1)T where in equation (59) F(s)=[coshΓl+cosΓl2sinhΓl+sinΓl2Γ-C2Γ(coshΓl-cosΓl)-C2ΓΓ(sinhΓl-sinΓl)Γ2(sinhΓl-sinΓl)12(coshΓl+cosΓl)-C2Γ(sinhΓl+sinΓl)-C2Γ(coshΓl-cosΓl)-Γ2C(coshΓl-cosΓl)-Γ2C(sinhΓl-sinΓl)12(coshΓl+cosΓl)12Γ(sinhΓl+sinΓl)-ΓΓ2C(sinhΓl+sinΓl)-Γ2C(coshΓl-cosΓl)Γ2(sinhΓl-sinΓl)12(coshΓl+cosΓl)]

The elements of the 4 × 4 irrational, non-linear matrix F(s) of equation (59) are formed from (60)f1=(coshγ+cosγ)/2 (61)f2=sinhγ+sinγ (62)f3=coshγ-cosγ and (63)f4=sinhγ-sinγ where in equations (60) to (63) (64)γ=Γ1/2l where l is the length of the distributed parameter shaft with (65)Γ1/2=s1/2(LC)1/4 (65)C=1EI and (67)L=ρA
